sentences.sentence: Today's expected announcement of the date for the Voice referendum will start concentrating the minds of many Australian voters on a cause that's become more troubled than when Prime Minister Anthony Albanese raised hopes in unveiling the wording of the proposed constitutional amendment at the 2022 Garma Festival 13 months ago.
The government now has an expected six-week campaign until referendum day - expected to be October 14 - to save the Yes case, which has been losing support across opinion polls throughout the year.

The Australian Financial Review supports both Indigenous recognition in the nation's founding Constitution and the principle of a well-functioning advisory body that, as compellingly argued by the Productivity Commission, Noel Pearson and others, could deliver the practical changes needed to end the shameful disadvantage among First Australians in remote and regional areas.Whatever the merits of the referendum proposition, it has turned out to be a high-risk exercise.
Unless the latest opinion polls are wrong, the best hope may be to just achieve the required double majority of more than 50 per cent of voters and four of the six states.
Mr Albanese may have assumed that the concept of the Voice would sell itself, getting over the line with a tailwind of national goodwill to reset history and improve Indigenous lives.

That might turn out to be the case on the day, especially with the extensive funding of the Yes cause and the institutional supporters, from big business through to academia and cultural and sporting bodies, that have lined up behind it.

But elite and celebrity feel-good support is no guarantee of success, as shown by the defeat of Australia's republic referendum in 1999, the UK Brexit vote in mid-2016 and the election of political huckster Donald Trump in the US in late 2016.It is hard to imagine that a No result would be other than a bitter setback for reconciliation of modern Australia's relationship with its First Peoples.

The risk flows not from the lack of goodwill among Australians, but from the uncertainties of the referendum proposition to entrench the Voice by creating a new, permanent chapter in the Constitution alongside the parliament, judiciary and executive government.

The final report of the Referendum Commission in 2017 says that the Voice should not be a veto, or a limit on parliament, and advise only on matters that particularly affect Indigenous people.Leading judges, jurists and constitutional experts say the Voice does not force parliament to listen.

But the extra 25 pages attached to the basic one-page Uluru Statement from the Heart do suggest a more expanded agenda than, for instance, Mr Pearson's insistence that the Voice will focus on practical measures to end extreme Indigenous disadvantage.

The ideas of Makaratta, or coming together after a struggle, truth-telling or a reckoning of what happened during Australia's colonial era and questions of unceded sovereignty and a treaty raise questions that Yes proponents would prefer to discuss later.
In putting the weight of his government behind this process, Mr Albanese clearly has not done enough to answer the questions of many Australians about what all this means.

The best result would be that the Yes case can use the next six weeks to convince Australians that a constitutionally embedded Voice would in practice advance the cause of Indigenous Australians in a way that unifies the nation.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Today's expected announcement of the date for the Voice referendum will start concentrating the minds of many Australian voters on a cause that's become more troubled than when Prime Minister Anthony Albanese raised hopes in unveiling the wording of the proposed constitutional amendment at the 2022 Garma Festival 13 months ago. The government now has an expected six-week campaign until referendum day - expected to be October 14 - to save the Yes case, which has been losing support across opinion polls throughout the year. The Australian Financial Review supports both Indigenous recognition in the nation's founding Constitution and the principle of a well-functioning advisory body that, as compellingly argued by the Productivity Commission, Noel Pearson and others, could deliver the practical changes needed to end the shameful disadvantage among First Australians in remote and regional areas.Whatever the merits of the referendum proposition, it has turned out to be a high-risk exercise. Unless the latest opinion polls are wrong, the best hope may be to just achieve the required double majority of more than 50 per cent of voters and four of the six states. Mr Albanese may have assumed that the concept of the Voice would sell itself, getting over the line with a tailwind of national goodwill to reset history and improve Indigenous lives. That might turn out to be the case on the day, especially with the extensive funding of the Yes cause and the institutional supporters, from big business through to academia and cultural and sporting bodies, that have lined up behind it. But elite and celebrity feel-good support is no guarantee of success, as shown by the defeat of Australia's republic referendum in 1999, the UK Brexit vote in mid-2016 and the election of political huckster Donald Trump in the US in late 2016.It is hard to imagine that a No result would be other than a bitter setback for reconciliation of modern Australia's relationship with its First Peoples. The risk flows not from the lack of goodwill among Australians, but from the uncertainties of the referendum proposition to entrench the Voice by creating a new, permanent chapter in the Constitution alongside the parliament, judiciary and executive government. The final report of the Referendum Commission in 2017 says that the Voice should not be a veto, or a limit on parliament, and advise only on matters that particularly affect Indigenous people.Leading judges, jurists and constitutional experts say the Voice does not force parliament to listen. But the extra 25 pages attached to the basic one-page Uluru Statement from the Heart do suggest a more expanded agenda than, for instance, Mr Pearson's insistence that the Voice will focus on practical measures to end extreme Indigenous disadvantage. The ideas of Makaratta, or coming together after a struggle, truth-telling or a reckoning of what happened during Australia's colonial era and questions of unceded sovereignty and a treaty raise questions that Yes proponents would prefer to discuss later. In putting the weight of his government behind this process, Mr Albanese clearly has not done enough to answer the questions of many Australians about what all this means. The best result would be that the Yes case can use the next six weeks to convince Australians that a constitutionally embedded Voice would in practice advance the cause of Indigenous Australians in a way that unifies the nation.
